data.name: text-1
data.value:
An adjective is a part of speech that denotes a sign of an object.
The adjective answers the questions: “what?”, “what?”, “what?”
Qualitative adjectives have a constant feature - they have long and short forms.
This article details the types ratios of two forms and illustrative examples are given to consolidate material.
What are the forms of adjectives?
In Russian, full and short forms of adjectives are distinguished.

This grammatical feature is permanent and is peculiar only to quality adjective:
  • 1. Full adjectives - attributive, inflected forms (change by gender, number, cases), neutral in meaning. IN sentences are most often used as definitions. Examples full adjectives: dry, cold, red, neat.
  • 2. Short adjectives - predicative, indeclinable forms (change only by gender and number, do not decline by cases), differ in book value. Proposals usually include nominal predicate. Examples of short adjectives: far, young, white, meek.

Types of ratios of full and short forms of adjectives.
Full and short forms of adjectives do not have all the words of this parts of speech.
By the presence (or absence) of this grammatical adjectives are divided into three groups:

  • 1. Adjectives that have both full and short forms (good is good, cheerful is cheerful, fresh is fresh, smart is smart). Brief forms are formed by adding shortened adjectives to the stem endings -а (-я), -о (-е), -ы (-и) and zero (cute - cute, strong - firmly).
  • 2. Adjectives that have only the full form. These include - adjectives with evaluation suffixes (tall, green), quality adjectives formed from relative ones (coffee, brown, milky), calling the colors of animals (bay, brown) and non-derivative adjectives (foreign, former).
  • 3. Adjectives that have only a short form (too small, necessary, much, happy).

data.name: text-2
data.value:
A noun is a part of speech that refers to an object and changes by cases and numbers.
The gender of nouns is a constant grammatical feature. The gender category of nouns is a grammatical feature, which gives us information about the generic affiliation of an object, a living being, phenomenon, or its absence.
* Only nouns in the singular form have gender.

Three kinds of nouns:
  • 1. Male - he, mine.
    Masculine nouns in the nominative case
    singular have the endings -а, -я, and zero.
    Examples of masculine nouns: brother, table, dad, eagle.
  • 2. Female - she, mine. Nominative feminine nouns singular have the endings -а, -я, and zero. Examples of feminine nouns: earth, cat, love.
  • 3. Medium - it's mine.
    Neuter nouns in the nominative case
    singular have endings -о, -е.
    Examples of neuter nouns: silver, sun, lake.

Determining the gender of nouns The gender of a noun can be determined by grammatical form of the adjective associated with it.
Like this:
  • 1. Masculine nouns agree with adjectives, that answer the questions: whose? Which? (red jacket, large box);
  • 2. Feminine nouns agree with adjectives, that answer the questions: whose? which? (fresh press, sad neighbor);
  • 3. Nouns of the middle gender are consistent with adjectives, that answer the questions: whose? which? (cat purring, high building).
* the category of gender cannot be determined for words that are used only in the plural: day, wallpaper, jeans, hide and seek, scissors, ink, chess, twilight.

Animated nouns have the same gender as the gender. belonging to a living being, person:
grandfather, interlocutor - husband. r.;
sister, saleswoman R.

Correct spelling: masculine/feminine/neuter noun kind.
But this is wrong: in the masculine / feminine / neuter gender. The thing is that "in" means a non-permanent feature. And the noun always there is a number, a case, and it is always of a certain gender.
Gender of indeclinable nouns Indeclinable nouns are borrowed from words in other languages that have the same grammatical form in all cases.
To determine the gender of an indeclinable noun, you need take into account the meaning of the word and the category of animateness / inanimateness. Animated nouns that name a person by gender, are categorized as masculine or feminine in meaning:
brilliant maestro - husband. r.
famous couturier - husband. r.
beautiful madam - wives. r.
young lady - female r.

Foreign words that name birds and animals have masculine category, if the context does not indicate a female:
bright hummingbird - husband. r.
motley cockatoo - husband. r.
furry chimpanzee - husband. p
wary chimpanzee - female. r.

In Russian, borrowed words retain the same gender as they were in a foreign version. This explains the fact that in modern Russian the words "piano", "coffee", "kangaroo" are masculine. "Salto", "chassis", "domino" are neuter, and "shawl" are feminine.
Inanimate nouns are most often neuter:
clean subway;
fun show;
cozy cafe;
fast taxi.

Some inanimate nouns have gender determined by key word:
green kohlrabi (cabbage) - for women. r.
salted suluguni (cheese) - husband. r.
big tornado (hurricane) - husband. r.
long avenue (street) - female. r.
delicious kiwi (berry) - female. r.
scoring penalty (free kick) - male. r.

In geographic names, you need to understand what kind of object we are talking about. and determine the genus by it:
City (Peter, Gelendzhik) - husband. r.
River (Mississippi, Congo) - female. r.
Lake (Baikal, Onega) - cf. r.

The genus of abbreviations can be determined by the main word. But before the abbreviation needs to be deciphered:
Moscow State University continued to recruit students. — Moscow State the university continued to recruit students.
MKAD will be rebuilt. — Moscow

data.name: text-3
data.value:
Case is a grammatical category of some parts of speech, which helps to coordinate words with each other in a sentence.
When changing words by case, they change the ending.

6 cases of the Russian language:
*The numbers in brackets are the serial number of the case in Russian.

  • 1) Nominative case (1). This is the form of the word given in dictionary.
    We always learn new words in the nominative form. For example: This is (what?) a house.
    (Who?) Mom cooks well.
  • 2) Prepositional case (6).
    For example: I live (where?) in Minsk (where?) on Chervyakova street.
    I work (where?) at a school.
    My sister studies (where?) at the university.
  • 3) Accusative case (4).
    For example: I see (what?) blue sky.
    I love (who?) my mother.
  • 4) Dative case (3).
    For example: I'm glad (what?) good weather.
    I give (to whom?) a friend a book.
  • 5) Genitive case (2).
    For example: I don't have (what?) a car.
    I like to walk without (who?) a dog.
  • 6) Instrumental case (5).
    For example: He has (what?) the flu.
    She works (by whom?) as a doctor.
